nodes.bodyText: You don't need this override, calling the management node method with a lock token is sufficient.
I don't know if this is the correct operator, what if there are multiple instants? .single() would throw an exception if there were more than one element.
Normally service would return one because we are sending one lock token . But  in track1 also , they are using same logic since AMQP message comes as array in case of one lock token.

Yes, and using .single() would force it to throw if there was more than one element in the flux. why not use .next() rather than .last() then? If the stream had 10000 elements, this would not complete until 9999 elements had been emitted.
that should be fine I guess.
Is there a reason you're creating another array with the same content?
removing it.
REQUEST_RESPONSE_RENEWLOCK_OPERATION -> REQUEST_RESPONSE_RENEW_LOCK_OPERATION
Prefixing these constants with request_response isn't necessary. It was because all their message constants were in the same file. Ones relevant to Management are in the ManagementConstants file.
LOCKTOKENS -> LOCK_TOKENS
What if the status isn't OK? We should return an error.
You need to run Alt+Shift+L to reformat the code. There is incorrect spacing on a few lines.
All this logic can be moved to MessageSerializer.
moved to serializer.
This unchecked cast makes me nervous. I would be more defensive about casting (ie. checking instanceof).
This variable creation isn't necessary if you're going to pass it immediately to the next line.
Instead of returning Flux.fromIterable, you could have kept it as a stream instead of collecting it twice and using fromStream
This already exists in AmqpResponseCode.
Remove these commented lines
Why not use a fake connection string rather than reading from the environment.

Asserts are for checking if the message you received is correct. You are doing a lot more logic here.
Consider using .then(Runnable)
We shouldn't be using Thread.sleep() to test or wait. StepVerifier was created so it could wrap the async operations and wait correctly.
Use clientlogger
This is a test. it should be in the test folder.
Undo this reformat. The parameters are all mushed against the right margin. I have it set in intellij not to align it.
is this what they do in track 1? update the actual parameter object itself? Since we want to make ServicebusReceivedMessage immutable, id expect a clone to be created.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -194,6 +194,46 @@ public String getServiceBusResourceName() {
         return defer(message, null);
     }
 
+    /**
+     * Asynchronously renews the lock on the message specified by the lock token. The lock will be renewed based on the
+     * setting specified on the entity. When a message is received in {@link ReceiveMode#PEEK_LOCK} mode, the message is
+     * locked on the server for this receiver instance for a duration as specified during the Queue creation
+     * (LockDuration). If processing of the message requires longer than this duration, the lock needs to be renewed.
+     * For each renewal, the lock is reset to the entity's LockDuration value.
+     *
+     * @param messageLock The {@link UUID} value of the message lock to renew.
+     *
+     * @return The {@link Mono} the finishes this operation on service bus resource.
+     */
+    public Mono<Instant> renewMessageLock(UUID messageLock) {
+        return connectionProcessor
+            .flatMap(connection -> connection.getManagementNode(entityPath, entityType))
+            .flatMap(serviceBusManagementNode -> serviceBusManagementNode
+                .renewMessageLock(messageLock));
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Asynchronously renews the lock on the specified message. The lock will be renewed based on the
+     * setting specified on the entity. When a message is received in {@link ReceiveMode#PEEK_LOCK} mode, the message is
+     * locked on the server for this receiver instance for a duration as specified during the Queue creation
+     * (LockDuration). If processing of the message requires longer than this duration, the lock needs to be renewed.
+     * For each renewal, the lock is reset to the entity's LockDuration value.
+     *
+     * @param receivedMessage to be used to renew.
+     *
+     * @return The {@link Mono} the finishes this operation on service bus resource.
+     */
+    public Mono<Instant> renewMessageLock(ServiceBusReceivedMessage receivedMessage) {
+        return connectionProcessor
+            .flatMap(connection -> connection.getManagementNode(entityPath, entityType))
+            .flatMap(serviceBusManagementNode -> serviceBusManagementNode
+                .renewMessageLock(receivedMessage.getLockToken())
+                .map(instant -> {
+                    receivedMessage.setLockedUntil(instant);

nodes.bodyText: You don't need this variable because you reassign it later anyways. Return a collections.emptylist in the other cases.

nodes.bodyText: This is never disposed of in @After
Like I said, according to the spec this will never be null.

I know you added comments and it doesn't make it reactive nor does it use StepVerifier correctly.

You've only hooked up the doOnNext, which is used for side effects like logging, but you use it for validation. the first overload of subscribe is a better fit.
What if the renewal fails? There is no handling of any error cases to fail the test
What if the operation never emits a value because it was hung? You don't handle that case either.

Since we are pressed for time, can you create an issue to write tests for this?
You could have used. repeat() here.
